title: Count returns an additional .groups column when applied to remote tables
body:
`count`  seem to return an additional `.groups` column when used on remote tables.

``` r
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
con <- DBI::dbConnect(RSQLite::SQLite(), ":memory:")
copy_to(con, mtcars)
DBI::dbListTables(con)
#> [1] "mtcars"       "sqlite_stat1" "sqlite_stat4"
con %>% 
  tbl("mtcars") %>% 
  count()
#> # Source:   lazy query [?? x 2]
#> # Database: sqlite 3.30.1 [:memory:]
#>       n .groups
#>   <int> <chr>  
#> 1    32 drop
```

title: tally() change in behavior: groups are dropped
body:
Based on the release notes for [`summarise()` and grouping](https://www.tidyverse.org/blog/2020/05/dplyr-1-0-0-last-minute-additions/#summarise-and-grouping), I believed that `tally()` might work the same way since it does so in the current version on CRAN:

``` r
library("dplyr")
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
starwars %>%
  group_by(homeworld, species) %>%
  summarise(n = n()) %>%
  head(3)
#> # A tibble: 3 x 3
#> # Groups:   homeworld [3]
#>   homeworld   species     n
#>   <chr>       <chr>   <int>
#> 1 Alderaan    Human       3
#> 2 Aleen Minor Aleena      1
#> 3 Bespin      Human       1
starwars %>%
  group_by(homeworld, species) %>%
  tally(wt = mass) %>%
  head(3)
#> # A tibble: 3 x 3
#> # Groups:   homeworld [3]
#>   homeworld   species     n
#>   <chr>       <chr>   <dbl>
#> 1 Alderaan    Human     128
#> 2 Aleen Minor Aleena     15
#> 3 Bespin      Human      79
```

<sup>Created on 2020-05-06 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>


However, on the current version on GitHub (0f7bb2223485cd47b33aebe02cca5a00538b102d), `tally()` drops, but `summarise()` does not. Is this intentional?

``` r
library("dplyr")
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
starwars %>%
  group_by(homeworld, species) %>%
  summarise(n = n()) %>%
  head(3)
#> `summarise()` regrouping by 'homeworld' (override with `.groups` argument)
#> # A tibble: 3 x 3
#> # Groups:   homeworld [3]
#>   homeworld   species     n
#>   <chr>       <chr>   <int>
#> 1 Alderaan    Human       3
#> 2 Aleen Minor Aleena      1
#> 3 Bespin      Human       1
starwars %>%
  group_by(homeworld, species) %>%
  tally(wt = mass) %>%
  head(3)
#> # A tibble: 3 x 3
#>   homeworld   species     n
#>   <chr>       <chr>   <dbl>
#> 1 Alderaan    Human     128
#> 2 Aleen Minor Aleena     15
#> 3 Bespin      Human      79
```

<sup>Created on 2020-05-06 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

title: `is_grouped_df()` does not return correct grouping status after calling `rowwise()`
body:
I'm using the dev version of dplyr `0.8.99.9002` and reading the help page for `?rowwise`:

> A row-wise tibble maintains its row-wise status until explicitly removed by group_by(), ungroup(), or as_tibble().

That would lead me to believe that the output of `mtcars %>% rowwise() %>% is_grouped_df()` would be `TRUE`, because I did not call any of the functions listed above after calling `rowwise()` in this pipe:

```R
mtcars %>% rowwise() %>% is_grouped_df()
#> [1] FALSE
```

Could this be a bug, or perhaps something was overlooked with either the `rowwise()` or `is_grouped_df()` functions?

title: group_split(keep=) -> group_split(.keep=)
body: probably also needs `group_map()` and `group_modify()`

title: Convert coalesece to use vctrs
body:
Fixes #5186

I'm slightly nervous about changing this at this point in release cycle, but I think it should be an innocuous change because it only increases the set of valid inputs.

title: df_patch (via coalesce) is too picky about types

labels.name: bug
labels.description: an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
``` r
library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)

df <- tibble(a = 1:3, b = letters[c(1:2, NA)], c = 0.5 + 0:2)
df %>% rows_patch(tibble(a = 2:3, b = "B"))
#> Matching, by = "a"
#> # A tibble: 3 x 3
#>       a b         c
#>   <int> <chr> <dbl>
#> 1     1 a       0.5
#> 2     2 b       1.5
#> 3     3 B       2.5
df %>% rows_patch(tibble(a = c(2, 3), b = "B"))
#> Matching, by = "a"
#> Error: Argument 2 must be an integer vector, not a double vector
```

<sup>Created on 2020-05-04 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

title: A na.rm option for cumany?
body:
Doing
```
cumany(c(NA,3) < 2)
```
I get `NA NA`. I would expect an option to do something like
```
cumany(c(NA,3, na.rm = TRUE) < 2)
```
in order to get `NA FALSE`. Is there a way?

Thank you!

title: adjacency grouping as a helper function
body:
This has been discussed in various issues and forums, notably:

- https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/237, suggesting `group_by_adj()` (suggesting pre-ordered adjacency);
- https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/1534;
- https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/1661; and
- https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/4445 (most recent)

One key difference is that some of those discussions focused on a new `group_by_*` verb, where I suggest having just a helper function is sufficient to scratch the itch sufficiently. Lacking safeguards and sanity checks, it could be as straight-forward as:

```r
rle_group <- function(...) {
  yy <- rle(paste(...))
  rep(seq_along(yy$lengths), yy$lengths)
}

df <- data.frame(x = c(0, 0, 1, 0), y = c(2, 2, 2, 2))
df %>%
  group_by(grp = rle_group(x, y))
# # A tibble: 4 x 3
# # Groups:   grp [3]
#       x     y   grp
#   <dbl> <dbl> <int>
# 1     0     2     1
# 2     0     2     1
# 3     1     2     2
# 4     0     2     3
```

The under-inspiring `Groups: grp` may not be as informative as [Romain's previous suggestion](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/237#issuecomment-35085223) of

```lang-r
> df <- data.frame( x = 1, a = rep(c(1,2), each = 4), b = rep( letters[1:2], each = 2), stringsAsFactors = TRUE )
> gdf <- grouped_df_adj_impl( df, list( quote(x), quote(a), quote(b) ), FALSE )
> summarise(gdf, n = n() )
Source: local data frame [4 x 4]
Groups: x, a

  x a b n
1 1 1 a 2
2 1 1 b 2
3 1 2 a 2
4 1 2 b 2
```

(where the `Groups: x, a` is more useful), it still enables the grouping.

This comes up frequently enough on StackOverflow that I think its utility is justified. I think the implementation could be innocuous enough to not impact other verbs.

The use of `paste` enables "one or more" columns, and happens to side-step `rle`'s avoidance of `factor`. It does add overhead, so a more performant variant might be supported (that does not omit `factor`s). I'd think a variant of [Hadley's initial suggestion](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/237#issuecomment-34117419) (Rcpp-based) could be adapted to handle one-or-more.

I'd be willing to start on a PR if maintainers support the concept.

title: Weird dbplyr error when the dev version of dplyr is installed
body:

title: `group_split()`'s `keep` argument should be `.keep`
body:
Because `...` is passed on to `group_by()` which has mutate-like semantics.

```r
library(dplyr)

df <- data.frame(x = 1:2)

group_split(df, y = 1:2)
#> [[1]]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 2
#>       x     y
#>   <int> <int>
#> 1     1     1
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 2
#>       x     y
#>   <int> <int>
#> 1     2     2
#> 
#> attr(,"ptype")
#> # A tibble: 0 x 2
#> # … with 2 variables: x <int>, y <int>

group_split(df, keep = 1:2)
#> [[1]]
#>   x
#> 1 1
#> 2 2
#> 
#> attr(,"ptype")
#> integer(0)
```

Would also align better with `nest_by()`

title: Strange issue when Spectrum and dplyr are loaded together
body:
Here is a strange problem that I ran into today. In RStudio with R 4.0 on both Mac and Linux, If I load the following packages together: 

```r
library(dplyr)
library(Spectrum)
```

and then try to run any function starting with "wrap", e.g.:

```r
wrap_test <- function() {
  "test"
}

wrap_test()
```

after using the RStudio autocomplete feature (tab) to complete the function's name, the R session freezes and starts using 100% of my CPU. I could not figure out what the issue was but I could reproduce it on my Mac and my Linux machines. I'm guessing some weird interaction between Spectrum and dplyr. I'll cross-post this on the Spectrum Github page.

title: Allow aggregate functions within `arrange`
body:
Inspired by [this Stack Overflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/q/61503447/903061), perhaps `arrange` should allow aggregate functions.

Want: order groups by aggregate function

Attempt:

```
mtcars %>% 
  group_by(cyl) %>%
  arrange(mean(mpg))
# Error: incorrect size (1) at position 1, expecting : 32
```

Workaround:

```
mtcars %>%
  mutate(cyl = forcats::fct_reorder(factor(cyl), mpg, .fun = mean)) %>%
  arrange(cyl)

## or (more literally)

mtcars %>% 
  group_by(cyl) %>% 
  mutate(mean_mpg = mean(mpg)) %>%
  arrange(mean_mpg) %>%
  select(-mean_mpg)
```

Could `arrange` recycle length-one inputs up to the group size? Would make it more consistent with `filter` and `mutate`.

title: Performance of select_if() over wide dataframes (2)
body:
Related to https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/2932.
`select_if(df, is.numeric)` seems unreasonably slow on a 10,000 column df and uses an insane amount of memory. Am I missing something? 
Would be happy to help with a fix on this if you think I could. I have package maintenance experience but no tidy eval experience.

``` r
suppressMessages(library(dplyr))

# create a data frame of 10,000 columns
df <- runif(1e4) %>% 
  magrittr::set_names(paste0("x", seq_along(.))) %>% 
  as.list() %>% 
  as_tibble()

bench::mark(
  select_if(df, is.numeric),
  df[vapply(df, is.numeric, logical(1))]
)
#> Warning: Some expressions had a GC in every iteration; so filtering is disabled.

title: nest_by doc improvements
body:
```R
# nest_by() needs to explain that:
mtcars %>% 
  group_by(cyl) %>% 
  summarise(data = list(cur_data())) %>% 
  rowwise()

# and unnest is equivalent to:
mtcars %>% 
  nest_by(cyl) %>% 
  summarise(data)
```

And emphasise that the result is `rowwise()`

title: nest_by improvements
body:
From @jennybc 

```R
mtcars %>% group_by(cyl) %>% nest_by()
# should be same as
mtcars %>% nest_by(cyl)

mtcars %>% group_by(cyl) %>% nest_by(vs)
# two source of grouping information - either ungroup()

```

title: Allow summarise() to explicitly control grouping
body:
The current grouping behaviour causes much confusion, and it's not correct now that summary expressions can return multiple values and rowwise is back to life. I now think the way to fix this is to add a `.groups` argument that could take any of the following values:

* `NULL` (default) = `"drop_last"` + message displaying the new grouping vars
* `"drop_last"`: current behaviour
* `"drop"`: returns ungrouped tibble
* `"keep"`: preserves existing grouping
* `"rowwise"`: one group per row

`summarise()` is the only verb that operates on "groups" (rather than rows or columns), so is the only function that needs this option.

cc @MilesMcBain

title: Rethink count()
body: Something seems fundamentally wrong with the design of `count()`, `add_count()`, `tally()`, and `add_tally()`. The functions are fragile, and seem to have too much magic.

title: Summarising across a difftime variable on a grouped dataframe has very poor performance

milestone.description: Things we'll deal with after 1.0.0 is released.

body:
Running a `summarise()` across a difftime variable on a grouped dataset has exceptionally poor performance. This is noticeable in that the poor performance doesn't occur in base R or data.table and also doesn't occur in dplyr if you cast the variable to numeric. 

Re-producible example below (using dplyr 0.8.5)



```r
n <- 2000000
library(dplyr)
library(data.table)

a = as.Date('2018-01-01')
b = as.Date('2019-01-01')

dat_num <- tibble(
    patientid = sample( 1:50000, replace = TRUE, size = n ),
    value = difftime(b, a, unit = "days")  %>% as.numeric()
)

dat_date <- tibble(
    patientid = sample( 1:50000, replace = TRUE, size = n ),
    value = difftime(b, a, unit = "days") 
)



### Dplyr - numeric (quick)
system.time({
    dat_num %>%
        group_by(patientid) %>%
        summarise( m = max(value))
})

### Dplyr - difftime (takes forever to run) 
system.time({
    dat_date %>%
        group_by(patientid) %>%
        summarise( m = max(value))
})


### Base R - numeric (quick)
system.time({
    tapply( X = dat_num$value, dat_num$patientid, max)
})

### Base R - difftime (quick)
system.time({
    tapply( X = dat_date$value, dat_date$patientid, max)
})


### data.table - numeric (quick)
system.time({
    x <- as.data.table(dat_num)
    x[, .(m = max(value)), by = patientid]
})

### data.table - difftime (quick)
system.time({
    x <- as.data.table(dat_date)
    x[, .(m = max(value)), by = patientid]
})

```


```

arch           x86_64

title: Experimenting with hybrid evaluation again.

milestone.description: Things we'll deal with after 1.0.0 is released.

body:
It's very shaky for now, here are some details: 

before the usual loop is evaluated with `mask$eval_all_summarise(quo)` this first calls `hybrid_eval_summarise()` which might return: 

 - `NULL` : hybrid evaluation failed, just proceed as normal
 - a list that may contain:
     - `$chunks`: the result chunks, this is what `mask$eval_all_summarise(quo)` would give
     - `$sizes`: same as `list_sizes($chunks)`
     - `$results`: same as `vec_c(!!!$chunks)`

Things are made complicated because `summarise()` no longer restricts output size to `1` so we can't just have `$results` but perhaps there  could be a way to make `$chunks` lazy as it might not be needed by follow up operations. 

Then there's `hybrid_eval_summarise()` which for now takes `mask` and `quo` as its arguments and uses `mask$current_vars()` and `mask$resolve()`. 

This leaves chopping responsibility to the DataMask class so that's good. 

At the moment, `hybrid_eval_summarise` looks at the call, but this part is even more sketchy

title: Revisit `dplyr::coalesce` with `across`
body:
With dplyr 1.0.0 introducing `c_across` and `across` I was wondering if it was possible to revisit #3548, by allowing `dplyr::coalesce` to work more naturally with the new `across` or `c_across` functions. 

After reading the [row-wise](https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/dev/articles/rowwise.html#row-wise-summary-functions) article, I expected `dplyr::coalesce` to work like `rowSums` since it naturally works across rows, or at worst it would work like `rowwise` => `sum`. 

However, `coalesce` doesn't seem to work with the `across` family at all, as you can see in the code below.

Would it be possible to make `coalesce` compatible with the new `across` workflow?

``` r
library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)

df <- tibble(
  id = 1:5, 
  w = c(10, NA, NA, NA, 14), 
  x = c(NA, 21, 22, 23, NA), 
  y = c(NA, NA, 32, 33, NA), 
  z = c(NA, NA, NA, 43, 44)
)

## Does coalesce work like rowSums, because
## they both naturally work across rows?
df %>%
  mutate(a = rowSums(across(-id), na.rm = TRUE))
#> # A tibble: 5 x 6
#>      id     w     x     y     z     a
#>   <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1    10    NA    NA    NA    10
#> 2     2    NA    21    NA    NA    21
#> 3     3    NA    22    32    NA    54
#> 4     4    NA    23    33    43    99
#> 5     5    14    NA    NA    44    58

# No: coalesce doesn't work like rowSums
df %>%
  mutate(a = coalesce(across(-id)))
#> # A tibble: 5 x 6
#>      id     w     x     y     z   a$w    $x    $y    $z
#>   <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1    10    NA    NA    NA    10    NA    NA    NA
#> 2     2    NA    21    NA    NA    NA    21    NA    NA
#> 3     3    NA    22    32    NA    NA    22    32    NA
#> 4     4    NA    23    33    43    NA    23    33    43
#> 5     5    14    NA    NA    44    14    NA    NA    44



## Maybe it works like sum, since coalesce's argument is `...`
df %>%
  rowwise() %>%
  mutate(a = sum(c_across(-id), na.rm = TRUE))
#> # A tibble: 5 x 6
#> # Rowwise: 
#>      id     w     x     y     z     a
#>   <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1    10    NA    NA    NA    10
#> 2     2    NA    21    NA    NA    21
#> 3     3    NA    22    32    NA    54
#> 4     4    NA    23    33    43    99
#> 5     5    14    NA    NA    44    58

# No: coalesce doesn't work with rowwise
df %>%
  rowwise() %>%
  mutate(a = coalesce(c_across(-id)))
#> Error: `mutate()` argument `a` must be recyclable.
#> ℹ `a` is `coalesce(c_across(-id))`.
#> ℹ The error occured in row 1.
#> x `a` can't be recycled to size 1.
#> ℹ `a` must be size 1, not 4.
#> ℹ Did you mean: `a = list(coalesce(c_across(-id)))` ?



## coalesce works if you write out each by hand,
## but that goes against the spirit of the new `across` family
df %>%
  mutate(a = coalesce(w, x, y, z))
#> # A tibble: 5 x 6
#>      id     w     x     y     z     a
#>   <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1    10    NA    NA    NA    10
#> 2     2    NA    21    NA    NA    21
#> 3     3    NA    22    32    NA    22
#> 4     4    NA    23    33    43    23
#> 5     5    14    NA    NA    44    14

# there is a work around suggested in #3548, but it's not very user friendly
# and requires a different package
library(tidyselect)
df %>%
  mutate(a = coalesce(!!!syms(vars_select(names(.), -id))))
#> # A tibble: 5 x 6
#>      id     w     x     y     z     a
#>   <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1    10    NA    NA    NA    10
#> 2     2    NA    21    NA    NA    21
#> 3     3    NA    22    32    NA    22
#> 4     4    NA    23    33    43    23
#> 5     5    14    NA    NA    44    14
```

title: Differentiate between wt = NULL and missing(wt)
body:
This makes the difference between a missing `wt` and setting `wt = NULL`, previously there was no way to cancel the "use `n` as the default `wt`" behavior. 

``` r
library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)

example <- tibble(
  x = c("a", "b", "c", "d", "e"),
  y = 1:5,
  n = 11:15
)

example %>% 
  count(x, name = "test")
#> Using `n` as weighting variable
#> # A tibble: 5 x 2
#>   x      test
#> * <chr> <int>
#> 1 a        11
#> 2 b        12
#> 3 c        13
#> 4 d        14
#> 5 e        15

example %>% 
  count(x, name = "test", wt = NULL)
#> # A tibble: 5 x 2
#>   x      test
#> * <chr> <int>
#> 1 a         1
#> 2 b         1
#> 3 c         1
#> 4 d         1
#> 5 e         1
```

title: Confusing error message inside `c_across()`
body:
I am using `rowwise()` and `c_across()` and encountered a confusing error message. Here is a toy case of my situation. I was counting the number of columns containing several strings. The selection inside the second `c_across()` captures the first variable that was `mutate`d, so it is trying to combine character and integer columns. 

``` r
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(stringr)
tibble(ai = c("a", "b", "a"), 
       bi = c("b", "b", "b"), 
       ci = c("a", "b", "c"), 
       d = c("a", "b", "a")) %>% 
  rowwise() %>% 
  mutate(ai_count = sum(str_detect(c_across(contains("i")), pattern = "a")),
         bi_count = sum(str_detect(c_across(contains("i")), pattern = "b")))
#> Error: `mutate()` argument `bi_count` must return compatible vectors across groups.
#> i `bi_count` is `sum(str_detect(c_across(contains("i")), pattern = "b"))`.
```

<sup>Created on 2020-04-09 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>


The error message `Error: `mutate()` argument `bi_count` must return compatible vectors across groups.` is confusing here. It seems to suggest it's a problem across the groups/rows, but it's actually an issue with concatenating variables of different types within the same group. Could this error message be made clearer here?

I also am rather confused as to why this errors at all. I would have expected `c_across()` to have similar coercion behavior as `c()` and to coerce the integer values to charcter.

title: make the promises throuh a function formals instead of env_bind_lazy()

body:
This tries to limit the setup cost when dealing with data frames with many columns, in particular when creating the promises that are associated with each column. This uses formal arguments instead of `rlang::env_bind_lazy()`. 

For example with a 10000 columns data frame, i.e. this code: 

```r
library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)
library(purrr)

idx <- 1:10000
df <- tibble(!!!set_names(map(idx, ~rnorm(1000)), paste0("x", idx)))

profvis::profvis(
  for(i in 1:100) summarise(df, mean(x1))
)
```

title: Add a `.method` argument to the data frame method of `arrange()`
body:
Closes #4962

This PR adds a `.method` argument to the data frame method of `arrange()`. It defaults to `"dplyr_auto"`, but can also be any valid `order()` method.

`"dplyr_auto"` is more aggressive than `"auto"` in two ways:

- In addition to integer, numeric and logical vectors, it also uses radix ordering for character vectors. This forces the use of a C-locale, but is very fast. This is a breaking change for the defaults of `arrange()`.

- It uses `typeof()` rather than `is.*()` functions when determining if radix ordering can be used to operate at a level lower than S3 dispatch. This probably doesn't matter too much, because it is called on the comparison proxies of the columns (which generally returns the underlying raw data), but it still felt more correct.

```r
library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)

set.seed(123)

size <- 1000000

df <- tibble(
  a = sample(c("a", "b", "c", "d"), size, replace = TRUE),
  b = sample(1:20, size, replace = TRUE)
)

# Master
bench::mark(arrange(df, a, b), iterations = 20)
#> # A tibble: 1 x 6
#>   expression             min   median `itr/sec` mem_alloc `gc/sec`
#>   <bch:expr>        <bch:tm> <bch:tm>     <dbl> <bch:byt>    <dbl>
#> 1 arrange(df, a, b)    1.99s    2.22s     0.449    41.1MB     1.80

# This PR
bench::mark(arrange(df, a, b), iterations = 20)
#> # A tibble: 1 x 6
#>   expression             min   median `itr/sec` mem_alloc `gc/sec`
#>   <bch:expr>        <bch:tm> <bch:tm>     <dbl> <bch:byt>    <dbl>
#> 1 arrange(df, a, b)   34.3ms   37.8ms      24.8    48.8MB     105.
```
